Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to leave for my volunteer shift. It was Jamie, my closest friend. Her voice trembled, and I could hear her sniffling. “Can you talk? I really need someone right now,” she said, her words heavy with emotion. I knew she’d had a rough week, and I wanted nothing more than to listen, to be there for her like she’d always been for me. But I glanced at the clock—my shift at the community center started in fifteen minutes, and I was the only one with the keys. People would already be waiting outside, counting on me to open up and start the day’s service. My heart pounded as I tried to split myself in two, torn between the friend Jamie needed and the volunteer everyone else was depending on. I could hear the desperation in her voice, but I also pictured the line forming at the center, people growing anxious in the morning chill. I gripped my phone, caught in the impossible space between two promises, unsure which one I was about to break.
